relate.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if two things relate, they are connected in some way
relate.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: I don’t understand how the two ideas relate.
The charges of fraud relate to events that took place over ten years ago.
relate.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people often say something has (something) to do with another thing, rather than relates to it:
The changes have to do with  events that took place over ten years ago.
I don't understand what the two ideas have to do with each other.
relate.translation[0].definitions[1].def: if you relate two different things, you show how they are connected
relate.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The report seeks to relate the rise in crime to an increase in unemployment.
relate.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to tell someone about events that have happened to you or to someone else
relate.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He later related the whole story to me.
relate.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to feel that you understand someone’s problem, situation etc
relate.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Laurie finds it difficult to relate to children.
I know he feels upset, and I can relate to that.
relate.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a British organization which helps those who have problems with relationships, especially marriage. It used to be called the Marriage Guidance Council.
